displayed_text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So this is quite a paradoxical approach. Patient: Okay, good. Doctor: And it turns out that you’re absolutely right. We’ve known for a long time for about seventy years that testosterone can feed into your prostate cancer. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: However, we have recently discovered in the last three or four years that they can take a patient who has had low testosterone levels for a very long time they call that hormone-resistant prostate cancer or castration-resistant prostate cancer is another term Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um many patients don’t like that term. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um so that’s just hormone resistant. Patient: Okay. Doctor: In that context only, if you give back super-high doses of testosterone to the patient, and the way that we do that is we give an intra-muscular injection. It’s an injection of testosterone into the muscle that is either thigh muscle or the butt muscle. Patient: Uh huh.

Family Member: He goes outside. Doctor: Yes. He’s got a little color. (Laughs) Patient: If it wasn’t for this darn ankle I’d be… Doctor: I think you know what you need to do about that. You just got to ease up man. Patient: Yeah I do. Yeah. Thank you. God bless you. Family Member: Thank you. Patient: And I think the world of you, this is still rolling. I think the world of you. Doctor: Just say I need a raise. Patient: Send her to Toledo for a vacation. (Laughs) Doctor: Nice. See ya. Patient: Yeah. (Door closes)

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And then so that could be one of the first things that drops the PSA and then we expect with that shot that you received that it’s going to drop it even further. And so that’s what we’re looking for today. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so we’re really with our fingers crossed that you know your cancer is shrinking and diving because of what we’ve done, and uh that the issue with that big amount of cancer that is around how your urine gets out of your body—that also will improve, and then we could think about getting your catheter out. Patient: Uh hum. That sounds good. Doctor: This is a copy for us. Patient: Yes. Family Member: Right. I have the originals - Family Member: Okay we have good questions. We talked about it – Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: - before and you told us to stay away from the Doctor: Yeah.

Patient: And, and I want you to know that I, I thought this discussion was going to be today. Doctor: I’m glad I met your expectations. Patient: Yeah. I thought this was going to come up, and I said, okay. But it is what it is. Healthcare Professional: I will communicate with L___, and she’ll contact you probably tomorrow, about she will get in contact with K. She will set everything up for you. Patient: Okay. Thank you. Doctor, it’s always good to see you. And thank you for your advice. And we’re going to follow your lead. Doctor: And I’ll follow your lead. We’ll help each other. Patient: Yes sir. Yes sir. Now, do I need to go to K___ to get a prescription? Doctor: You’ll wait to hear from us. L___ will help us to do that. L___ will help us to get the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Because normally I think the last two times we were able to, I just told them I would pay for them out of pocket here, but that’s okay. Doctor: I wouldn’t recommend that. Patient: Oh kay. Healthcare Professional: I’m going to give you my card with my number, in case you don’t hear from L___ tomorrow. MD Exits

Patient: You know? J___ will probably ask more. (Laughs) Doctor: As I expect her to. (Laughs) Patient: She’s my little warrior. Doctor: Huh. I know. Patient: You know? It was you know I, I can of expected it. I was worried about hearing that but you’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. Doctor: You’ve got to do what you’ve got to do. And you know we could always switch course elsewhere. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I mean this is. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I have to say, though, that you look better today post radiation than before we started. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You were really uncomfortable. You know? Patient: Yeah. And now I did have some.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.strongly agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::strongly agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.disagree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::disagree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.White: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::White

displayed_text: Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay? So we’ll check probably after about twelve weeks, huh, about how it’s going. Huh, but our job will be to cheer lead you through the first three to four cycles, huh, adjusting the dose if you’re having side effects and they’re too severe. But most people are able to get through it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so my recommendation is that we stop the abiraterone, continue the prednisone. If you’re interested in the clinical trial, I can at least start with, huh, printing it out for you, and letting you read it, and see how often you need to be here, let the nurse know that you’re potentially interested, and she can, huh, do insurance clearance. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So if they say your insurance is not going to pay for it, the decision’s made. Patient: Right. Doctor: If the decision says the insurance will cover it, after you’ve read it, huh, you could say, yeah, I’m interested. And then we’ll bring you back to have a formal discussion about what that looks like. Okay? Patient: Okay. Doctor: Huh, so all that can happen in the next three to four weeks. Huh, so you come off the abiraterone. We’ll see if this gets better. Watch your potassium. But you do some reading. Huh, if there’s other people you want to talk about the trial, people that have been on it, huh, or have any concerns about, you know, being here so much, let us know, because we can work on some of that with you. Patient: Now, the only thing, huh, mainly. The vitamin C, if I get it, I might not use something, and if I don’t get it, it ain’t going to affect the chemo I’m getting to try to do-? Doctor: Right. Because that’s what everybody gets. That’s what everybody gets. Patient: Right.

Patient: Um Hmm. Doctor: -you’re coming back. Call me a little hyper-anal. Doctor: Yes. Let’s do that. Doctor: I am. Good plan. Right? Plus it’ll keep you more on track if you know that you have to come in and we check your sugars and yeppers. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That’s it. Patient: Okay. I am getting a shot today? Doctor: Um hum. Patient: And I do have it here? Doctor: I think so. Was there a question on that? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I wasn’t aware of-

Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So again, you have my blessing, so to speak, but I would also like a second person’s approval as well. Patient: Right. Doctor: Given the primary care provider who’s known you for a long time Patient: Right. Yeah, share it with my primary care, Dr____. Doctor: Now your PSA level from two weeks ago, I think it was third. Patient: Two months, two weeks, yeah. Doctor: Was at zero point five. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: Okay, so that’s very good news because it’s a very slight - Patient: Okay. Doctor: So it was zero point three. The time before that it was like two months before and went from point three to point five. Patient: Uh huh.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Do you have any other questions that arise immediately that you want to discuss? Patient: Uh, and you may not be able to are you gonna be able to check when Doctor: Yeah so that’s a good question. So um there’s an easy answer to that and there’s a more easy answer to that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: The easy answer is if you ever develop symptoms from your cancer. For example, if the cancer has spread to your bone or if the cancer in the lymph node causing a blood obstruction. stop the Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: So if someone has an intermediate or low Gleason score, the PSA level is less than fifty it’s rising at a slow pace… it’s better after six months. to start the hormone therapy. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: Unless, the PSA or Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: But to me if it’s a combination of both factors. Again, if you ever have a symptom from your cancer, then typically that is what I would strongly recommend.

Patient: No, no. Doctor: Ooo, it’s a little gooey under there, it is. Patient: What’s that? Doctor: A little gooey under there! Patient: Yeah. Patient: Well, that’s that the uh, ointment. Doctor: And did you see any of your blood tests and lab results? Patient: I did. Doctor: Your, uh, white count, uh, was okay. You’re less anemic than you have been, so did you get a blood transfusion or anything? Patient: No. (laughter) Doctor: Are you drinking enough fluid? You’re not dehydrated and concentrated yourself up? Patient: No.

Patient: Uh, and then look at the other options. So, is that, is the one that is phase one is that, that window like a real tight window. That seven days from now, it’s gonna be closed? Doctor: Umm. I don’t know that. So, when I spoke to Dr. P_, all she let me know was that there was a slot. You know, that would be something that we would say once you’ve decided or that we’ve given you the consent form that we have a potential patient who’s interested, that they would save that slot for you. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because they would, I assume, that there is going to need to be a twenty-eight day washout of your current therapy. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then, maybe that you have to repeat scans prior to that. Um, the adrenal glands. The, the big wild card there right now what I can clearly state that it is not specific. I don’t know what it is. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And again, that’s the radiologists can’t agree on what it is. Patient: So, would I have to have something done to go into the adrenal glands or, uh, the, the tests that confirm that whether it is cancer or not cancer? Doctor: Um, no. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. And then if you decided to go with chemotherapy, it would be just one of the many spots that we would watch for change in response to.

Family Member: …it’s dead quiet on Tuesday’s you know so that works out real well. But - Doctor: Perfect. Family Member: Obviously if it doesn’t work that way then we’ll just have to deal with it. Doctor: We’ll work around your schedule for that. Once we plan what study, then absolutely. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: As far as possible, I prefer Tuesday’s too so I would try and keep you on that. Family Member: Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But uh we’ll see how it goes. Family Member: Alright. I know in the beginning it will be more - Doctor: Next week though I was going to say just so we have enough time to get the results back, we should plan for like Thursday or Friday so we give it enough time because you know my worry is if I have you come in next Tuesday I may not have the results back from today’s blood work. Patient: Yeah, right. Family Member: So back here next Thursday or Friday?

Patient: Oh yeah, they said for pain, and I didn’t need that. Doctor: Well that’s for spasm, but they also give you medicine for pain, Hydro-per ; so you can take either of those two medicines. Doctor: So five milligrams Patient: What’s a spasm? Family Member: Spasm. Doctor: Uh your bladder. You feel a cramping down. Patient: No, I didn’t feel that. Doctor: So that’s . And then you also are taking calcium. Family Member: No. Doctor: Just the Vitamin D. Patient: Just Vitamin D. Patient: I used to take that when I was playing actively tennis, but I haven’t been playing tennis now for a while, so

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay your testosterone is not as low as I would like it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s it’s low, but it should be lower ideally with the Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your next Lupron which is tomorrow is happening with R____. Patient: Right… Doctor: Right? Patient: …and after that you guys are supposed to take it over. Doctor: Okay, alright we’ll do that. Patient: I don’t ever see Dr. R____ no more over there. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: No I ain’t saw you either. (Laughs) Doctor: W____ will come in with the paperwork and then we’ll get you out of here. Patient: Okay fine. Doctor: Okay? Any questions? Patient: No. Doctor: No? Patient: No not really. Doctor: Okay. Patient: Not at this point anyway. Doctor: Awesome. Happy New Year to both of you. Family Member: Thank you. Doctor: Nice to see you, nice to see you.
